verses.text: Do not be jealous of your wife's beauty, and do not let her draw you away with your eyes.
verses.comment: This verse warns against both jealousy and lust, emphasizing trust and respect within marriage. The New Testament deepens this teaching with Christ's call to purity of heart (Matt 5:28).

verses.text: Do not give your soul to a woman, so that she may trample on your strength.
verses.comment: This echoes earlier wisdom literature warning that immoral relationships can weaken spiritual strength. Compare with Proverbs 31:3 and a christological call to holiness.

verses.text: Do not meet with a harlot, or you may fall into her snares.
verses.comment: Contact with sexual sin is seen as a snare. The literal meaning affirms traditional sexual ethics rooted in wisdom literature.

verses.text: Do not linger with a singer, or you may be caught by her tricks.
verses.comment: This refers to women who might seduce through entertainment. The theme is guarding the senses and heart, a principle valued in ascetic spiritual traditions.

verses.text: Do not gaze upon a young girl, or you may be ensnared with her beauty.
verses.comment: Originating in the wisdom tradition, purity of heart is a universal Christian value. Jesus' intensification in Matthew 5:28 is foreshadowed here.

verses.text: Do not give yourself to prostitutes, or you may destroy your inheritance.
verses.comment: Wasting blessings through vice is an ancient theme, underlining the need for chastity to preserve spiritual inheritance.

verses.text: Do not look around in the streets of a city, or wander about in deserted places.
verses.comment: Idle behavior in public can lead to temptation. Tradition encourages vigilance and avoidance of occasions of sin.

verses.text: Turn your eye away from a beautiful woman, and do not gaze upon another's beauty.
verses.comment: Closely tied to Christ’s warning against lust in the heart. Maintaining custody of the eyes is a longstanding spiritual practice.

verses.text: With a married woman do not dine, or you will cause your heart to slip toward her and be destroyed by your passion.
verses.comment: There are repeated warnings about emotional and physical infidelity. The literal and spiritual sense both reinforce marital fidelity.

verses.text: Do not abandon an old friend, for a new one cannot take his place.
verses.comment: Faithfulness in friendship parallels God’s steadfast faithfulness. The continuity of relationship echoes divine covenant continuity.

verses.text: Do not despise a wise teacher, for you do not know his true worth.
verses.comment: Valuing those who impart wisdom is critical. Jesus affirms the reward for receiving a prophet or righteous person.

verses.text: Delight not in the downfall of sinners; remember, we are all subject to punishment.
verses.comment: This verse invites humility and mercy, recalling Jesus’ teaching to avoid judging others.

verses.text: Do not turn away from someone who is humble, but remember that those who are unseen may be greatly esteemed.
verses.comment: God exalts the humble—see Jesus in Luke 14:11. The spiritual sense points to the dignity of humility and hidden sanctity.

verses.text: Do not look down on anyone who is old, for some among them also learn wisdom.
verses.comment: Respect for age and wisdom is a recurring theme in Scripture and the tradition of the Church.

verses.text: Do not rejoice at the death of anyone. Remember, we will all face death.
verses.comment: A call to reflect on our mortality, fostering humility and preparation for judgement—a theme echoed in Christian tradition.

verses.text: Speak with those who are wise, and let your conversation be about the Law of the Most High.
verses.comment: The Law here anticipates the fullness of revelation, encouraging ongoing meditation and community grounded in God's Word.

verses.text: Let righteous people be at your table, for your glory will be in the fear of the Lord.
verses.comment: Table fellowship is a sign of holiness and communion; sharing with the righteous foreshadows the heavenly banquet.

verses.text: A work is praised for the skill of the craftsman, so a ruler is proved wise in the counsel of elders.
verses.comment: Good leadership relies on wise counsel—a model mirrored in the New Testament Church’s decisions (Acts 15:6). Wise guidance and unity are enduring principles for the Christian community.
